title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. His mom had insisted joining a club would help him make friends at his new school. "I'm Jake. I signed up yesterday," he mumbled. Someone snickered in the back. The blue-haired girl's face suddenly broke into a wide grin. "Perfect timing! We need someone to test our robot obstacle course." The way she exchanged glances with the others made Jake wonder if he was about to become part of an experiment rather than part of the team.

Jake shifted his weight from one foot to the other as the girl with bright blue hair approached him. She extended her hand with a smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. "I'm Mia, team captain. We're working on battle bots this semester." The other students huddled around a table covered with metal parts, wires, and tools Jake couldn't name. One boy nudged another and whispered something that made them both snicker. Mia led Jake to the workstation, pointing to a half-assembled robot with exposed circuits. "This one needs programming help. Can you code?" Jake nodded slowly, though he'd only done basic tutorials online. The fluorescent lights buzzed overhead as he set his backpack down and pulled out his laptop. A tall boy with glasses slid a notebook toward him filled with complicated diagrams. Jake swallowed hard, wondering what he'd gotten himself into.

Jake swallowed hard, wondering what he'd gotten himself into. The robotics club room buzzed with activity as students hunched over tables covered with wires, circuit boards, and half-built machines. A tall girl with curly hair stepped forward from the crowd. "You must be Jake," she said with a friendly smile. "I'm Mia, the club president." Jake nodded, his grip on his backpack loosening slightly. Mia pointed to an empty seat at a table where two boys were working on what looked like a small car. "You can join Team Voltage over there. They're building a robot for the maze competition next month." Jake made his way across the room, carefully stepping around toolboxes and robot parts scattered on the floor. As he sat down, one of the boys handed him a shiny red apple. "Brain food," the boy explained with a grin. "You'll need it for programming day."

Jake nodded quickly, trying to remember where he had put his laptop that morning. The robotics club room buzzed with activity as students unpacked equipment and chatted about coding challenges. A tall girl with curly hair waved Jake over to an empty seat beside her workstation. "I'm Mia, team captain," she said, pointing to the complex robot on her desk. "We're building battle bots this semester." Jake noticed something shiny attached to the robot's arm that looked like a miniature SWORD, though it was probably just a metal attachment for picking up objects. His nervousness began to fade as Mia showed him how to connect to the school's programming network. Maybe this club wouldn't be so intimidating after all. Jake unzipped his backpack and pulled out his laptop, ready to join his first programming session.

Jake unzipped his backpack and pulled out his laptop, ready to join his first programming session. His hands trembled slightly as he found an empty seat at the back of the room. The club president, a tall girl with glasses, walked over and introduced herself as Mia. "We're coding movement patterns for the competition robots today," she explained, pointing to a small tank-like machine on the center table. Jake nodded, trying to appear confident despite feeling completely lost. The other students were already typing away, their fingers flying across keyboards. Jake opened his laptop and stared at the blank screen, not knowing where to begin. Mia noticed his confusion and sat beside him. "Don't worry," she whispered, "everyone starts somewhere." She showed him how to download the basic software, and Jake felt his shoulders relax a little as the program loaded.

The software finished loading with a soft chime, and Jake glanced up at the large clock on the wall. It was already 4:30, but time seemed to be moving faster now that he was actually doing something. "Great, now we can start programming your first robot," Emma said, pulling over a small kit with metal parts and wires. She showed him how to connect the motors to the control board while other club members worked on their own projects around the room. The buzz of conversation and occasional laughter made the lab feel less intimidating than when he'd first walked in. Jake carefully followed Emma's instructions, his tongue sticking out slightly as he concentrated on attaching a tiny screw. When the robot's wheels finally moved forward at his command, a smile spread across his face. Maybe joining robotics club wasn't such a bad idea after all.

Jake felt a smile spread across his face as he looked around the robotics lab. The other students had already returned to their projects, the initial awkwardness forgotten. Over the past few weeks, he had learned to program, build mechanical arms, and even helped the team win their first competition. Today, they celebrated with pizza and soda while planning their next robot design. Ms. Chen, their advisor, handed Jake a small trophy with his name engraved on it for "Most Improved Member." Outside the window, autumn leaves danced in the wind, reminding Jake how much time had passed since that nervous first day. As the bell rang and everyone packed up, several teammates high-fived him and asked if he'd join them at the mall later. Jake nodded happily, no longer the scared new kid but a valued member of the robotics family.
